page.title: Ohio State University Health Sciences Center for Global Health

revision.text:
[[Image:Health Sciences Center for Global Health.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Health Sciences Center for Global Health
[[John A Prior Health Sciences Library]]
376 W 10th Ave, Suite 165
Columbus, OH 43210-1280 ]] The '''Health Sciences Center for Global Health (HSCGH)''' at The [[Ohio State University]] (OSU) is a collaborative program among the OSU Colleges of Dentistry, Medicine, Nursing, Optometry, Pharmacy, Public Health, School of Health and Rehabilitation Sciences and Veterinary Medicine. The HSCGH is led jointly by the Colleges of Medicine (COM) and Public Health (CPH). The HSCGH was created to increase student interest in global careers, prepare students for those careers and to promote, develop and coordinate [[interdisciplinary]] [[global health]] education and research throughout the [[health sciences]] colleges and the larger community. The Board of Trustees approved the creation of the HSCGH in July 2007.[http://trustees.osu.edu/Minutes/documents/071307.pdf The Ohio State University (Columbus, Ohio), Minutes of the Meetings of the Board of Trustees, Meetings of 12, 13 July 2007](Retrieved on July 7, 2009) The [[National Institutes of Health]] (NIH) Fogarty Framework Grant[http://crisp.cit.nih.gov/crisp/CRISP_LIB.getdoc?textkey=7498897&p_grant_num=1R25TW008101-01&p_query=&ticket=84886286&p_audit_session_id=394817094&p_keywords= "OSU Center for Global Health, Grant Number: 1R25TW008101-01,"] Computer Retrieval of Information on Scientific Projects, National Institutes of Health (Retrieved on July 16, 2009) was awarded to OSU in September 2008.[http://www.fic.nih.gov/programs/training_grants/framework/awards_2008.htm "John E. Fogarty International Center Framework Programs for Global Health Fiscal Year 2008 Awards,”] U.S. National Institutes of Health (Retrieved on July 08, 2009)[http://www.nih.gov/news/health/sep2008/fic-10.htm "NIH Awards $4.6 Million to Expand Global Health Network,"] Press release (Retrieved on 2009-07-08) The NIH [[John E. Fogarty International Center]] grant supports the creation of new, multidisciplinary educational programs as well as an administrative infrastructure to support activities.[http://www.fic.nih.gov/programs/training_grants/framework/index.htm "John E. Fogarty International Center Framework Programs for Global Health,”] U.S. National Institutes of Health (Retrieved on July 08, 2009) ==Core Activities== *Creation of an administrative framework to coordinate and accelerate global health activities at OSU. *Development of robust multidisciplinary curricula in global health at the college-preparatory, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels for students and trainees enrolled at OSU. *Creation of an Interdisciplinary Specialization in Global Health within the Graduate School. *Development of mentored hands-on research, outreach and clinical experience in global health. == Graduate Interdisciplinary Specialization in Global Health == The '''Graduate Interdisciplinary Specialization in Global Health (GISGH)'''[http://medicine.osu.edu/globalhealth/8371.cfm Graduate Interdisciplinary Specialization in Global Health,"] The Ohio State University Health Sciences Center for Global Health (Retrieved on July 16, 2009) is a university-wide program that offers current OSU graduate and [[professional students]] advanced educational opportunities in the field of global health. The goal of the GISGH is to help prepare graduates to be active participants in the advancement of global health through academic enrichment, service-learning, and research pertaining to issues of global health. The specialization's core course, Introduction to Global Health, focuses on the basic components of population health, while the electives allow students to pursue topics across the other health sciences colleges for a truly interdisciplinary experience. == Leadership == '''Diane L. Gorgas, MD,''' a professor of Emergency Medicine at The Ohio State University’s Wexner Medical Center. She currently serves as the Executive Director of the Office of Global Health. and of OSU's Health Sciences Center for Global Health. She is nationally involved as an item writer and case developer and case administrator for the American Board of Emergency Medicine (ABEM) and sits on the Emergency Medicine Review Committee for the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME). She was the Residency Training Program Director in Emergency Medicine for many years, and has a long standing interest in and study of educational methods. Her other associated research interests include global health, emotional intelligence, competency assessment and learning styles. Dr. Gorgas currently directs the OSU Greif Neonatal Survival program, which works to improve the lives of mothers and infants in low-income countries through self-sustaining education and training programs to increase the in-country capacity of healthcare workers. '''Pamela Potter''' serves as the administrative director for the Health Sciences Center for Global Health at The Ohio State University and in that role provides oversight of the daily administration and operation of the center. She is also the associate director of the Office of Global Health in the College of Medicine. Prior to her role at OSU, she served as the Chief of Staff to the Executive Dean for the [[Georgetown University School of Medicine]]. ==Notes== ==External links== *[http://globalhealth.osu.edu/ Health Sciences Center for Global Health] ===OSU Health Sciences Colleges=== *[http://hrs.osu.edu/ School of Health and Rehabilitation Sciences] *[https://dentistry.osu.edu/ College of Dentistry] *[http://medicine.osu.edu/ College of Medicine] *[https://nursing.osu.edu/ College of Nursing] *[http://optometry.osu.edu/ College of Optometry] *[http://www.pharmacy.ohio-state.edu/ College of Pharmacy] *[http://cph.osu.edu/ College of Public Health] *{{webarchive |url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20020914174817/http://www.vet.ohio-state.edu/ |title=College of Veterinary Medicine |date=2002-09-14}} {{Ohio State University|academics}} [[Category:Ohio State University]] [[Category:Global health]] [[Category:Health education]]

{{Global surveillance}}
The '''origins of [[global surveillance]]''' can be traced back to the late 1940s, when the [[UKUSA Agreement]] was jointly enacted by the United Kingdom and the United States, whose close cooperation eventually culminated in the creation of the global surveillance network, code-named "'''[[ECHELON]]'''", in 1971.<ref>{{cite news|title=Q&A: What you need to know about Echelon|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sci/tech/1357513.stm|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=29 May 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Nabbali|first=Talitha|author2=Perry, Mark|title=Going for the throat|journal=Computer Law & Security Review|date=March 2004|volume=20|issue=2|pages=84–97|doi=10.1016/S0267-3649(04)00018-4|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0267364904000184|quote=It wasn't until 1971 that the UKUSA allies began ECHELON}}</ref>
In the aftermath of the [[Watergate scandal|1970s Watergate affair]] and a subsequent [[congressional inquiry]] led by Sen. [[Frank Church]],<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/homefront/preemption/telecoms.html Pre-Emption - The Nsa And The Telecoms | Spying On The Home Front | FRONTLINE | PBS<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> it was revealed that the NSA, in collaboration with Britain's GCHQ, had routinely intercepted the international communications of prominent anti-[[Vietnam War]] leaders such as [[Jane Fonda]] and Dr. [[Benjamin Spock]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Cohen |first=Martin |title=No Holiday |url= |location=New York |publisher=Disinformation Company Ltd |isbn=978-1-932857-29-0}}</ref> Decades later, a multi-year investigation by the [[European Parliament]] highlighted the NSA's role in [[Industrial espionage|economic espionage]] in a report entitled 'Development of Surveillance Technology and Risk of Abuse of Economic Information', in 1999.<ref>{{Cite report |author=Peggy Becker |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=October 1999 |title=DEVELOPMENT OF SURVEILLANCE TECHNOLOGY AND RISK OF ABUSE OF ECONOMIC INFORMATION |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/stoa/cms/cache/offonce/home/publications/studies?page=12 |publisher=STOA, European Parliament |page= |docket= |accessdate=November 3, 2013 |quote= }}</ref>
However, for the general public, it was a series of detailed disclosures of internal NSA documents in June 2013 that first revealed the massive extent of the NSA's spying, both foreign and domestic. Most of these were leaked by an ex-contractor, [[Edward Snowden]]. Even so, a number of these older global surveillance programs such as [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]], [[XKeyscore]], and [[Tempora]] were referenced in the 2013 release of thousands of documents.<ref>[http://tv.msnbc.com/2013/07/15/snowden-has-thousands-of-damaging-nsa-documents-says-greenwald/ Snowden has ‘thousands’ of damaging NSA documents, says Greenwald]</ref> As confirmed by the NSA's director [[Keith B. Alexander]] on September 26, 2013, the NSA collects and stores all phone records of all American citizens.<ref>{{cite news|title=Senators: Limit NSA snooping into US phone records|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/senators-limit-nsa-snooping-us-phone-records|work=Associated Press|accessdate=October 15, 2013|quote="Is it the goal of the NSA to collect the phone records of all Americans?" Udall asked at Thursday's hearing. "Yes, I believe it is in the nation's best interest to put all the phone records into a lockbox that we could search when the nation needs to do it. Yes," Alexander replied.}}</ref> Much of the data is kept in large storage facilities such as the [[Utah Data Center]], a US$1.5 billion [[megaproject]] referred to by ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' as a "symbol of the spy agency's surveillance prowess."<ref>{{cite news|last=Siobhan Gorman|title=Meltdowns Hobble NSA Data Center|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304441404579119490744478398|publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''|accessdate=October 19, 2013|quote=The Utah facility, one of the Pentagon's biggest U.S. construction projects, has become a symbol of the spy agency's surveillance prowess, which gained broad attention in the wake of leaks from NSA contractor Edward Snowden.}}</ref>
== Clandestine surveillance in the United States == {{Main article|Mass surveillance in the United States}}
[[File:Albert Einstein Head.jpg|thumb|200px|Due to his alleged ties to [[communism]], the German-born physicist [[Albert Einstein]] was placed under surveillance by the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) shortly after he [[emigration|emigrated]] to America. The FBI [[mail cover|monitored Einstein's mail]], [[phone bug|intercepted his telephone calls]], and searched his trash.<ref name="einsteinnytimes"/>]] [[File:Muhammad Ali NYWTS.jpg|thumb|200px|The American boxer [[Muhammad Ali]], a self-declared [[Vietnam War]] conscientious objector, was targeted by the NSA's [[Project MINARET]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Ryan Gallagher|title=Documents Show the NSA Spied on Muhammad Ali, Martin Luther King Jr., and ... Art Buchwald|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2013/09/26/minaret_nsa_surveillance_program_spied_on_muhammad_ali_martin_luther_king.html|publisher=''[[Slate (magazine)]]''|date=2002-05-07|accessdate=October 27, 2013}}</ref>]]
Wartime censorship of communications during the World Wars was paralleled by peacetime decipherment of communications by the [[Black Chamber]] (Cipher Bureau, MI-8), operating with the approval of the [[U.S. State Department]] from 1919 to 1929.<ref name="reutershistory">{{cite news|title=Factbox: History of mass surveillance in the United States|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/07/us-usa-security-records-factbox-idUSBRE95617O20130607|agency=Reuters|accessdate=August 14, 2013|date=June 7, 2013}}</ref> In 1945 the now-defunct [[Project SHAMROCK]] was created to gather all [[telegraph]]ic data entering into or exiting from the United States.<ref name="reutershistory"/><ref>{{cite web |last=The Center for Cryptologic History |url=http://www.nsa.gov/publications/publi00015.cfm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040318034627/http://www.nsa.gov/publications/publi00015.cfm |archivedate=March 18, 2004 |title=The Origins of NSA (NSA.gov) |publisher=Web.archive.org}}</ref> Major communication companies such as [[Western Union]], [[RCA|RCA Global]] and [[ITT Corporation|ITT World Communications]] actively aided the U.S. government in the latter's attempt to gain access to international message traffic.<ref name="pbs">{{cite web|last1=Epsley-Jones |first1=Katelyn |first2=Christina |last2=Frenzel|title=The Church Committee Hearings & the FISA Court |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/homefront/preemption/churchfisa.html |publisher=PBS |accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref>
In 1952, the NSA was officially established.<ref name="reutershistory"/> According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', the NSA was created in "absolute secrecy" by [[Harry Truman|President Truman]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Bamford |first=James |title=The Agency That Could Be Big Brother|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/25/weekinreview/25bamford.html?pagewanted=print|work=The New York Times|accessdate=August 14, 2013 |date=December 25, 2005}}</ref> Six weeks after President Truman took office, he ordered [[Telephone tapping|wiretaps]] on the telephones of [[Thomas Gardiner Corcoran]], a close advisor of [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]].<ref>{{cite news|last=DAVID BURNHAM|title=TRUMAN WIRETAPS ON EX-NEW DEAL AIDE CITED|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/02/01/us/truman-wiretaps-on-ex-new-deal-aide-cited.html|publisher=''The New York Times''|accessdate=September 18, 2013|date=February 1, 1986}}</ref> The recorded conversations are currently kept at the [[Harry S. Truman Presidential Library and Museum]], along with other sensitive documents ([http://www.trumanlibrary.org/hstpaper/psf.htm ~233,600 pages]).
Under [[J. Edgar Hoover]], the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) carried out wide-ranging surveillance of communications and political expression, targeting many well-known speakers such as [[Albert Einstein]],<ref name="einsteinnytimes">{{cite news|title=New Details Emerge From the Einstein Files; How the F.B.I. Tracked His Phone Calls and His Trash|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/07/science/new-details-emerge-einstein-files-fbi-tracked-his-phone-calls-his-trash.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|accessdate=September 17, 2013|first=Dennis|last=Overbye|date=May 7, 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=FBI campaign against Einstein revealed|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sci/tech/2033324.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=September 17, 2013|date=June 8, 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Albert Einstein: Fact or Fiction?|url=http://www.history.com/topics/einsteins-life-facts-and-fiction|publisher=[[History (U.S. TV channel)]]|accessdate=September 17, 2013|quote=Because of his controversial political beliefs-his support for socialism, civil rights, and nuclear disarmament, for example-many anti-Communist crusaders believed that Einstein was a dangerous subversive. Some, like FBI director J. Edgar Hoover, even thought he was a spy. For 22 years, Hoover's agents tapped Einstein's phones, opened his mail, rifled through his trash and even bugged his secretary's nephew's house, all to prove that he was more radical (as his 1,500-page FBI dossier noted) than "even Stalin himself."}}</ref> [[Frank Sinatra]],<ref>{{cite news|last=RONALD J. OSTROW and LISA GETTER|title=FBI Files on Sinatra Detail Links to JFK, Mob Figures|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/dec/09/news/mn-52274|publisher=''Los Angeles Times''|accessdate=September 18, 2013|date=December 9, 1998}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=MOLOTSKY|first=IRVIN|title=F.B.I. Releases Its Sinatra File, With Tidbits Old and New|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/09/us/fbi-releases-its-sinatra-file-with-tidbits-old-and-new.html|publisher=''The New York Times''|accessdate=September 18, 2013|date=December 9, 1998}}</ref> First Lady [[Eleanor Roosevelt]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Question: Why is Eleanor Roosevelt's FBI file so large?|url=http://www.gwu.edu/~erpapers/teachinger/q-and-a/q31.cfm|publisher=[[George Washington University]]|accessdate=September 18, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Eleanor Roosevelt|url=http://www.history.com/topics/eleanor-roosevelt|publisher=[[History (U.S. TV channel)]]|accessdate=September 18, 2013|quote=J. Edgar Hoover (1895–1972), the longtime director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, considered Eleanor Roosevelt’s liberal views dangerous and believed she might be involved in communist activities. He ordered his agents to monitor Roosevelt and keep what became an extensive file on her.}}</ref> [[Marilyn Monroe]],<ref name="apmonroe">{{cite news|title=FBI removes many redactions in Marilyn Monroe file|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/fbi-removes-many-redactions-marilyn-monroe-file|work=Associated Press|accessdate=September 18, 2013}}</ref> [[John Lennon]],<ref name="nytimesbeatles">{{cite news|last=Cohen|first=Adam|title=While Nixon Campaigned, the F.B.I. Watched John Lennon|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/21/opinion/21thu4.html|publisher=''The New York Times''|accessdate=September 18, 2013|date=September 21, 2006}}</ref> [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Martin Luther King, Jr. FBI File|url=http://library.truman.edu/microforms/martin_luther_king.asp|publisher=Pickler Memorial Library ([[Truman State University]])|accessdate=September 17, 2013}}</ref><ref name=Church>{{citation|last=Church|first= Frank|authorlink= Frank Church|title= Church Committee Book III| work =Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Case Study| publisher= [[Church Committee]]| date=April 23, 1976}}</ref> A FBI memo recognized King to be the "most dangerous and effective [[Negro]] leader in the country.",<ref name="mlkcommunism">{{cite news|title=FBI tracked King's every move|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/US/03/31/mlk.fbi.conspiracy/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=September 17, 2013|date=December 29, 2008}}</ref> and [[Daniel Ellsberg]],<ref>{{cite web|title='Life Lessons' From a White House Plumber|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=14468307|publisher=[[NPR]]|quote=When Daniel Ellsberg leaked the Pentagon Papers to The New York Times in 1971, the Nixon White House tried to discredit him. Among other things, Nixon loyalists burglarized the office of Ellsberg's psychiatrist.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The Watergate Story|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/watergate/timeline.html|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=September 17, 2013|quote=The White House "plumbers" unit - named for their orders to plug leaks in the administration - burglarizes a psychiatrist's office to find files on Daniel Ellsberg, the former defense analyst who leaked the Pentagon Papers.}}</ref> Some of these activities were eventually uncovered in the aftermath of the [[Watergate scandal]], leading to the [[Resignation of Richard Nixon]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Watergate and the Constitution|url=https://www.archives.gov/education/lessons/watergate-constitution/|publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|accessdate=September 17, 2013}}</ref>
{{Quotation| '''INVESTIGATIONS: Nobody Asked: Is It Moral?'''
''It did not matter that much of the information had already been released —or leaked—to the public. The effect was still overwhelming: a stunning, dismaying [[indictment]] of U.S. [[Intelligence agency|intelligence agencies]] and six [[President of the United States|Presidents]], from [[Franklin Roosevelt]] to [[Richard Nixon]], for having blithely violated [[Democracy|democratic ideal]]s and [[Human rights|individual rights]] while gathering information at home or conducting [[clandestine operation]]s abroad...''
|'''''[[Time (magazine)|Time magazine]]'', May 10, 1976'''<ref>{{cite news|title=INVESTIGATIONS: Nobody Asked: Is It Moral?|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,914164,00.html|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''|date=May 10, 1976}}</ref> }}
== Mass surveillance in a global context (1940–2001) == {{Main article|ECHELON}}
[[File:Mandela voting in 1994.jpg|thumb|200px|South Africa's anti-[[apartheid]] President [[Nelson Mandela]] was closely watched by British [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]] agents.<ref>{{cite news|title=British intelligence 'birdwatchers spied on Nelson Mandela's hideout'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/nelson-mandela/10169630/British-intelligence-birdwatchers-spied-on-Nelson-Mandelas-hideout.html|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|accessdate=September 21, 2013|location=London|first=Aislinn|last=Laing|date=July 9, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Nelson Mandela ‘was spied on by MI6 birdwatchers’|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/world/africa/article3812361.ece|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|accessdate=September 21, 2013}}</ref>]] [[File:Diana, Princess of Wales 1997 (2).jpg|thumb|200px|[[Diana, Princess of Wales|Princess Diana]]'s phone calls were monitored and recorded by the NSA right until she died in a 1997 [[Death of Diana, Princess of Wales|Paris car crash]].<ref>{{cite news|title=NSA Admits to Spying on Princess Diana|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/daily/dec98/diana12.htm|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=September 21, 2013|date=December 12, 1998}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=David Hencke and Rob Evans|title=US holds secret files on Diana|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/1999/aug/06/monarchy.freedomofinformation|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=August 6, 1999}}</ref>]]
During World War II the U.K. and U.S. governments entered into a series of agreements for sharing of [[signals intelligence]] of enemy communications traffic.<ref name="BRUSA papers">U.S. National Security Agency. [http://www.nsa.gov/public_info/_files/ukusa/early_papers_1940-1944.pdf Early Papers Concerning US-UK Agreement – 1940–1944] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130918015422/http://www.nsa.gov/public_info/_files/ukusa/early_papers_1940-1944.pdf |date=September 18, 2013}}. Agreement between British Government Code and Cipher School and U.S. War Department dated May 17, 1943. Retrieved: October 5, 2013.</ref> In March 1946, a secret agreement, the "[[1943 BRUSA Agreement|British-US Communication Intelligence Agreement]]", known as BRUSA, was established, based on the wartime agreements. The agreement "tied the two countries into a worldwide network of listening posts run by [[Government Communications Headquarters]] (GCHQ), the U.K.'s biggest spying organisation, and its U.S. equivalent, the National Security Agency."<ref name="Guardian 2010">{{cite news|last=Norton-Taylor|first=Richard|title=Not so secret: deal at the heart of UK-US intelligence|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/25/intelligence-deal-uk-us-released|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=June 25, 2010|accessdate=June 25, 2010|location=London}}</ref>
In 1988, an article titled "Somebody's listening" by [[Duncan Campbell (journalist)|Duncan Campbell]] in the ''[[New Statesman]]'', described the signals intelligence gathering activities of a program code-named "[[ECHELON]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Campbell |first=Duncan |authorlink=Duncan Campbell (journalist) |title=Somebody's Listening |newspaper=[[New Statesman]] |date=August 12, 1988 |url=http://duncan.gn.apc.org/echelon-dc.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070103071501/http://duncan.gn.apc.org/echelon-dc.htm |archivedate=January 3, 2007 |accessdate=September 16, 2013}}</ref> The program was engaged by English-speaking World War II [[Allies of World War II|Allied powers]] Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the United States (collectively known as [[AUSCANNZUKUS]]). Based on the [[UKUSA Agreement]], it was created to monitor the military and diplomatic communications of the [[Soviet Union]] and its [[Eastern Bloc]] allies during the [[Cold War]] in the early 1960s.<ref name = EP>{{cite web |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?pubRef=-//EP//NONSGML+REPORT+A5-2001-0264+0+DOC+PDF+V0//EN&language=EN |title=On the existence of a global system for the interception of private and commercial communications (ECHELON interception system), (2001/2098(INI)) |last=Schmid |first=Gerhard |date=July 11, 2001 |format=PDF |page=194 |publisher=European Parliament: Temporary Committee on the ECHELON Interception System |accessdate=September 16, 2013}}</ref> Though its existence had long been known, the UKUSA agreement only became public in 2010. It enabled the U.S. and the U.K. to exchange "knowledge from operations involving intercepting, decoding and translating foreign communications." The agreement forbade the parties to reveal its existence to any third party.<ref name="Guardian 2010"/>
By the late 1990s the [[ECHELON]] system was capable of intercepting satellite transmissions, [[public switched telephone network]] (PSTN) communications (including most Internet traffic), and transmissions carried by microwave. A detailed description of ECHELON was provided by New Zealand journalist [[Nicky Hager]] in his 1996 book "Secret Power". While the existence of ECHELON was denied by some member governments, a report by a committee of the [[European Parliament]] in 2001 confirmed the program's use and warned Europeans about its reach and effects.<ref name="online.wsj.com">Fiddler, Stephen (July 1, 2013). [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323936404578579811316559112 Echoes of Echelon in Charges of NSA Spying in Europe]. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''.</ref> The European Parliament stated in its report that the term "ECHELON" was used in a number of contexts, but that the evidence presented indicated it was a signals intelligence collection system capable of interception and content inspection of telephone calls, fax, e-mail and other data traffic globally. The report to the European Parliament confirmed that this was a "global system for the interception of private and commercial communications."<ref name=EP/>
{{Quotation |'''Echelon spy network revealed'''
'' Imagine a global spying network that can eavesdrop on every single [[phone call]], [[fax]] or [[e-mail]], anywhere on the planet. It sounds like science fiction, but it's true. Two of the chief protagonists - [[UKUSA Agreement|Britain and America]] - officially deny its existence. But the [[BBC]] has confirmation from the [[Australian Government]] that such a network really does exist..."''
|'''The British Broadcasting Corporation ([[BBC]]), November 1999'''<ref>{{cite news|last=Andrew Bomford|title=Echelon spy network revealed|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/503224.stm|publisher=BBC|date=November 3, 1999}}</ref> }}
== 9/11 and its implications on global surveillance (2001–2009) == {{Further information|NSA warrantless surveillance (2001–07)}}
[[File:Kofi Annan.jpg|thumb|200px|The 7th U.N. Secretary-General [[Kofi Annan]] was placed under surveillance by British intelligence agents, who bugged his office in the lead up to the [[Iraq War]].<ref>{{cite news|title=UK 'spied on UN's Kofi Annan'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/3488548.stm|publisher=BBC|date=February 2004}}</ref>]] [[File:Ban Ki-moon headshot.jpg|thumb|200px|The 8th U.N. Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] was placed under surveillance by U.S. diplomats, who also collected [[Iris recognition|iris scan]]s, [[fingerprint]]s and [[DNA]] of foreign diplomats, according to leaked documents released by [[WikiLeaks]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Paul Richter and Ken Dilanian|title=U.S. diplomats ordered to gather data on counterparts, WikiLeaks releases show|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/nov/29/world/la-fg-1129-wikileaks-20101129|work=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=17 December 2013|date=November 29, 2010}}</ref><ref name="clintonbankimoon">{{cite web|title=US diplomats spied on UN leadership |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/nov/28/us-embassy-cables-spying-un|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=August 27, 2013}}</ref>]] In the aftermath of the [[September 11 attacks]] in 2001 on the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] and [[the Pentagon]], the scope of domestic spying in the United States increased significantly. The bid to prevent future attacks of this scale led to the passage of the [[Patriot Act]]. Later acts include the [[Protect America Act]] (which removes the warrant requirement for government surveillance of foreign targets<ref name="Judiciary Testimony">{{cite web |date=September 18, 2007 |title=Warrantless Surveillance and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act: The Role of Checks and Balances in Protecting Americans' Privacy Rights (Part II): Hearing Before the H. Comm. on the Judiciary, 110th Cong. 13–30 (statement of J.M. McConnell, Director of National Intelligence) |url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CHRG-110hhrg37844/pdf/CHRG-110hhrg37844.pdf}}</ref>) and the [[FISA Amendments Act]] (which relaxed some of the original FISA court requirements).
In 2005, the existence of [[STELLARWIND]] was revealed by [[Thomas Tamm]]. On January 1, 2006, days after ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote that "''Bush Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts'',<ref name="nytimes123">{{cite news |last1=Risen |first1=James |last2=Lichtblau |first2=Eric |title=Bush Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/16/politics/16program.html?pagewanted=all|work=The New York Times|quote=The White House asked The New York Times not to publish this article |accessdate=August 14, 2013 |date=December 16, 2005}}</ref> the President emphasized that "''This is a limited program designed to prevent attacks on the United States of America. And I repeat, limited.''"<ref name="White House">{{cite web |date=January 1, 2006 <!-- , 12:05 PM CST --> |title=President Visits Troops at Brooke Army Medical Center |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2006/01/20060101.html |publisher=White House|accessdate=August 15, 2013}}</ref>
In 2006, [[Mark Klein]] revealed the existence of [[Room 641A]] that he had wired back in 2003.<ref name=WiredEvidence>{{cite journal |url=https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2006/05/70908 |title=AT&T Whistle-Blower's Evidence |journal=Wired |date=May 17, 2006 |accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref> In 2008, Babak Pasdar, a computer security expert, and CEO of [[Bat Blue]] publicly revealed the existence of the "Quantico circuit", that he and his team found in 2003. He described it as a back door to the federal government in the systems of an unnamed wireless provider; the company was later independently identified as [[Verizon]].<ref name="Poulsen">{{cite news|last=Poulsen|first=Kevin|title=Whistle-Blower: Feds Have a Backdoor Into Wireless Carrier — Congress Reacts|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2008/03/whistleblower-f/|work=Wired|accessdate=August 14, 2013|date=March 6, 2008}}</ref> Additional disclosures regarding a mass surveillance program involving U.S. citizens had been made in the U.S. media in 2006.<ref name="usatoday2006">{{cite news |last1=Cauley |first=Leslie |title=NSA has massive database of Americans' phone calls |url=http://yahoo.usatoday.com/news/washington/2006-05-10-nsa_x.htm |work=USA Today |date=May 11, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130713213322/http://yahoo.usatoday.com/news/washington/2006-05-10-nsa_x.htm |archivedate=July 13, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
{{Quotation |'''You Are a Suspect''' ''Every purchase you make with a [[credit card]], every [[magazine]] [[Subscription business model|subscription]] you buy and [[medical prescription]] you fill, every Web site you visit and [[e-mail]] you send or receive, every [[Academic grading in the United States|academic grade]] you receive, every [[Deposit account|bank deposit]] you make, every trip you book and every event you attend—all these transactions and communications will go into what the [[United States Department of Defense|Defense Department]] describes as a virtual, centralized grand database. To this computerized dossier on your private life from commercial sources, add every piece of information that government has about you—[[passport]] application, [[driver's license]] and [[Toll bridge|toll records]], judicial and [[divorce]] records, complaints from nosy neighbors to the F.B.I., your lifetime paper trail plus the latest hidden camera surveillance—and you have the supersnoop's dream: a [[Total Information Awareness]] about every U.S. citizen.''
|'''''[[The New York Times]]'', November 2002'''<ref>{{cite news|author=William Safire|title=You Are a Suspect|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/11/14/opinion/you-are-a-suspect.html |work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=September 20, 2013|date=November 14, 2002}}</ref> |qalign = left }}
== Acceleration of media leaks (2010–present) == On November 28, 2010, [[WikiLeaks]] and five major news outlets in Spain (''[[El País]]''), France (''[[Le Monde]]''), Germany (''[[Der Spiegel]]''), the United Kingdom (''[[The Guardian]]''), and the United States (''[[The New York Times]]'') began publishing the first 220 of 251,287 leaked [[United States diplomatic cables leak|U.S. State department diplomatic "cables"]] simultaneously.<ref>{{cite web|title=WikiLeaks FAQ: What Do the Diplomatic Cables Really Tell Us?|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/wikileaks-faq-what-do-the-diplomatic-cables-really-tell-us-a-731441.html|work=Der Spiegel|accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref>
On March 15, 2012, the American magazine ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' published an article with the headline "The NSA Is Building the Country's Biggest Spy Center (Watch What You Say)",<ref name="wired11">{{cite news|title=The NSA Is Building the Country's Biggest Spy Center (Watch What You Say)|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/03/ff_nsadatacenter/all/1|work=Wired|accessdate=August 14, 2013|first=James|last=Bamford|date=March 15, 2012}}</ref> which was later mentioned by U.S. Rep. [[Hank Johnson]] during a congressional hearing. In response to Johnson's inquiry, NSA director [[Keith B. Alexander]] testified that these allegations made by ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' magazine were untrue.<ref name="forbes1">{{cite news|last=Greenberg|first=Andy|title=NSA Chief Denies Wired's Domestic Spying Story (Fourteen Times) In Congressional Hearing|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2012/03/20/nsa-chief-denies-wireds-domestic-spying-story-fourteen-times-in-congressional-hearing/|work=Forbes|accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref>
In early 2013, [[Edward Snowden]] handed over 200,000 [[top secret]] documents to various media outlets, triggering one of the biggest [[news leak]]s in the modern [[history of the United States]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ex-CIA employee source of leak on PRISM program|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20130609-former-cia-employee-source-us-intelligence-leaks-snowden-nsa|publisher=[[France 24]]|accessdate=September 17, 2013|quote=Snowden’s decision to reveal his identity and whereabouts lifts the lid on one of the biggest security leaks in US history and escalates a story that has placed a bright light on Obama’s extensive use of secret surveillance.}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} {{flu}} The '''pandemic severity index''' ('''PSI''') is a proposed classification scale for reporting the severity of [[influenza pandemic]]s in the United States. The PSI was accompanied by a set of guidelines intended to help communicate appropriate actions for communities to follow in potential [[pandemic]] situations.<ref name=HHS>[[Department of Health & Human Services]], (2007) [http://www.pandemicflu.gov/plan/community/community_mitigation.pdf Interim Pre-Pandemic Planning Guidance: Community Strategy for Pandemic Influenza Mitigation in the United States— Early, Targeted, Layered Use of Nonpharmaceutical Interventions] (Full Text of the Initial Report outlining PSI), [[Centers for Disease Control]], USA</ref> Released by the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]] (HHS) on 1 February 2007, the PSI was designed to resemble the [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale]] classification scheme.<ref>{{cite news | title=U.S. Health Officials Unveil Flu Pandemic Plan | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/01/AR2007020101246.html | quote=U.S. health officials on Thursday outlined an early-warning system similar to that employed for hurricanes to protect and mobilize the country against a flu pandemic. |work=Washington Post |date=1 February 2007 | accessdate=2007-08-21 | first=Amanda | last=Gardner}}</ref><ref name=ties>{{cite news | last=Roos | first=Robert |author2=Lisa Schnirring | title=HHS ties pandemic mitigation advice to severity | publisher=[[CIDRAP]] News | date=1 Feb 2007 | url=http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/panflu/news/feb0107pandemic.html | accessdate=2007-08-11 }}</ref>
==Development== The PSI was developed by the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) as a new pandemic influenza planning tool for use by states, communities, businesses and schools, as part of a drive to provide more specific community-level prevention measures.<ref name=unveils>{{cite press release | title=HHS unveils two new efforts to advance pandemic flu preparedness | publisher=Office of Enterprise Communication, Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention | date=2007-02-01 | url=https://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/pressrel/2007/r070201a.htm | accessdate=2007-08-11 }}</ref> Although designed for domestic implementation, the HHS has not ruled out sharing the index and guidelines with interested international parties.<ref name=simple>{{cite news | last=Pellerin | first=Cheryl | title=Simple Planning Tools Can Help in Early Days of Pandemic | publisher=[[USINFO]] | date=12 Feb 2007 | url=http://www.america.gov/st/washfile-english/2007/February/20070212130917lcnirellep0.3025629.html | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128201729/http://www.america.gov/st/washfile-english/2007/February/20070212130917lcnirellep0.3025629.html | archivedate=28 November 2010 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The index and guidelines were developed by applying principles of [[epidemiology]] to data from the history of the last three major flu pandemics and [[seasonal flu]] transmission, mathematical models, and input from experts and citizen focus groups.<ref name=ties/> Many "tried and true"<ref name=praise>{{cite news | last=Roos | first=Robert |author2=Lisa Schnirring | title=Experts give qualified praise to new pandemic guidance | publisher=[[CIDRAP]] News | date=2007-02-02 | url=http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/panflu/news/feb0207reactions.html | accessdate=2007-08-11 }}</ref> practices were combined together in a more structured manner:-
{{quote|We also realize as we look back through history is what cities did – 44 cities did, is that many of these measures ultimately every city adopted at some point or another, and the difference may be in the timing of using these measures and whether they're coordinated in an effective way for us to really gain the benefits of them.|Dr Martin Cetron, Director of CDC's Division of Global Migration and Quarantine<ref name=transcript/>}}
==Context== During the onset of a growing pandemic, local communities cannot rely upon widespread availability of [[antiviral drug]]s and [[influenza vaccine|vaccine]]s<ref name=simple/><ref name=usatoday>{{cite news | last = Manning | first = Anita | title = Government issues pandemic flu plans |work=USA Today | date = 2 Feb 2007 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/2007-02-01-flu_x.htm }}</ref> (See [[Influenza research]]). The goal of the index is to provide guidance as to what measures various organizations can enact that will slow down the progression of a pandemic, easing the burden of stress upon community resources while definite solutions, like drugs and vaccines, can be brought to bear on the situation. The CDC expects adoption of the PSI will allow early co-ordinated use of community mitigation measures to affect pandemic progression.<ref name =ties/>
==Guidelines== The index focuses less on how likely a disease will spread worldwide – that is, become a pandemic – and more upon how severe the epidemic actually is.<ref name = transcript>{{cite press release | title=Update of Pandemic Flu Preparedness | publisher=Office of Enterprise Communication, Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control | date=1 February 2007 | url=https://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/transcripts/%20t070201.htm | accessdate=2007-08-11 }}</ref> The main criterion used to measure pandemic severity will be [[case-fatality ratio]] (CFR), the percentage of deaths out of the total reported cases of the disease.<ref name=ties/>
The actual implementation of PSI alerts is expected to occur after the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) announces [[WHO pandemic phases|phase 6]] influenza transmission (human to human) in the United States. This would probably result in immediate announcement of a PSI level 3–4 situation.<ref name=ties/>
{{anchor|Categories}}The analogy of "category" levels were introduced to provide an understandable connection to [[Tropical cyclone scales|hurricane classification]] schemes, with specific reference to the recent aftermath of [[Hurricane Katrina]].<ref name=unveils/><ref name=transcript/> Like the [[Saffir–Simpson Hurricane Scale]], the PSI ranges from 1 to 5, with Category 1 pandemics being most mild (equivalent to [[seasonal flu]]) and level 5 being reserved for the most severe "worst-case" scenario pandemics (such as the 1918 [[Spanish flu]]).<ref name=ties/><ref name=unveils/> [[Image:CDC Pandemic severity index.png|thumb|450px|right|A graphical representation of the PSI categorization scheme]] <center> {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+CDC Pandemic Severity Index chart<ref name=HHS/> ! Category !! CFR !! example(s) |- ! 1 | less than 0.1% || seasonal flu and [[H1N1|Swine Flu]]<ref name=simple/><ref name=reuters>{{cite news | last = Fox | first = Maggie | title = Swine flu death rate similar to seasonal flu: expert |agency=Reuters | date = 16 Sep 2009 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/healthNews/idUSTRE58E6NZ20090916 }}</ref> |- ! 2 | 0.1–0.5% || [[H2N2#Asian flu|Asian flu]] and [[H3N2#Hong Kong Flu|Hong Kong flu]] |- ! 3 | 0.5–1% || |- ! 4 | 1.0%–2.0% || |- ! 5 | 2.0% or higher || [[Spanish flu]] |} </center>
The report recommends four primary [[social distancing]] measures for slowing down a pandemic: * Isolation and treatment of people who have suspected or confirmed cases of pandemic influenza * Voluntary home quarantine of household contacts of those with suspected or confirmed pandemic influenza * Dismissing school classes and closing daycare centers * Changing work schedules and canceling large public gatherings<ref name=HHS/>
These actions, when implemented, can have an overall effect of reducing the number of new cases of the disease; but they can carry potentially adverse consequences in terms of community and social disruption.<ref name=unveils/> The measures should have the most noticeable impact if implemented uniformly by organizations and governments across the US.<ref name=unveils/><ref name=simple/><ref name=praise/>
==Response== While unveiling the PSI, Dr. [[Martin Cetron]], Director for the Division of Global Migration and Quarantine at the CDC, reported that early feedback to the idea of a pandemic classification scale has been "uniformly positive".<ref name=transcript/>
The [[University of Minnesota]]'s [[Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy]] (CIDRAP) reports that the PSI has been "drawing generally high marks from public health officials and others, but they say the plan spells a massive workload for local planners". One MD praised that the PSI were "a big improvement over the previous guidance"; while historical influenza expert and author [[John M. Barry]] was more critical of the PSI, saying not enough emphasis was placed on basic health principles that could have an impact at the community level, adding "I'd feel a lot more comfortable with a lot more research [supporting them]".<ref name=praise/>
During the initial press releases in 2007, the CDC acknowledge that the PSI and the accompanying guidelines were a work in progress and will likely undergo revision in the months following their release.<ref name=unveils/>

{{Distinguish|Planetary boundary layer}} {{bots|deny=Citation bot}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} [[File:Planetary Boundaries 2015.svg|thumb|400px|Planetary boundaries according to Rockström ''et al''. 2009 and Steffen ''et al.'' 2015. The green areas represent human activities that are within safe margins, the yellow areas represent human activities that may or may not have exceeded safe margins, the red areas represent human activities that have exceeded safe margins, and the gray areas with red question marks represent human activities for which safe margins have not yet been determined.]] '''Planetary boundaries''' is a concept involving Earth system processes which contain environmental boundaries, proposed in 2009 by a group of [[Earth system science|Earth system]] and [[environmental science|environmental scientists]] led by [[Johan Rockström]] from the [[Stockholm Resilience Centre]] and [[Will Steffen]] from the [[Australian National University]]. The group wanted to define a "safe operating space for humanity" for the international community, including governments at all levels, international organizations, civil society, the scientific community and the [[private sector]], as a precondition for [[sustainable development]]. The framework is based on scientific evidence that human actions since the [[Industrial Revolution]] have become the main driver of global environmental change. According to the paradigm, "transgressing one or more planetary boundaries may be deleterious or even catastrophic due to the risk of crossing thresholds that will trigger non-linear, abrupt environmental change within continental-to planetary-scale systems."{{cite web|url=https://pdxscholar.library.pdx.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1063&context=iss_pub|title=Planetary Boundaries: Exploring the Safe Operating Space for Humanity|year=2009|authors=Rockström et al.}} The Earth system process boundaries mark the safe zone for the planet to the extent that they are not crossed. As of 2009, two boundaries have already been crossed, while others are in imminent danger of being crossed.Editorial, {{Harvnb|Nature|2009}}. ==History of framework== [[File:Planetary Boundaries.png|thumb|Planetary boundaries diagram of 2009.]] In 2009, a group of [[Earth system science|Earth system]] and [[environmental science|environmental scientists]] led by [[Johan Rockström]] from the [[Stockholm Resilience Centre]] and [[Will Steffen]] from the [[Australian National University]] collaborated with 26 leading academics, including [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|Nobel]] laureate [[Paul Crutzen]], [[Goddard Institute for Space Studies]] climate scientist [[James Hansen]] and the [[German Chancellor]]'s chief climate adviser [[Hans Joachim Schellnhuber]] and identified nine "planetary life support systems" essential for human survival, attempting to quantify how far seven of these systems had been pushed already. They estimated how much further humans can go before [[planetary habitability]] is threatened.{{Harvnb|Rockström|Steffen|26 others|2009}}. Estimates indicated that three of these boundaries—[[climate change]], [[biodiversity]] loss, and the biogeochemical flow boundary—appear to have been crossed. The boundaries were "rough, first estimates only, surrounded by large uncertainties and knowledge gaps" which interact in complex ways that are not yet well understood. Boundaries were defined to help define a "safe space for human development", which was an improvement on approaches aiming at minimizing [[Human impact on the environment|human impacts]] on the planet. The 2009 report was presented to the General Assembly of the [[Club of Rome]] in Amsterdam.{{Harvnb|Rockström|2009}} (presentation). An edited summary of the report was published as the featured article in a special 2009 edition of ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]''.{{Harvnb|Rockström|others|2009b}}. alongside invited critical commentary from leading academics like Nobel laureate [[Mario J. Molina]] and biologist [[Cristián Samper]].{{Harvnb|Molina|2009}}. [http://nceas.ucsb.edu/files/news/comment.pdf Planetary boundaries]: A series of commentaries in ''Nature reports climate change'' on the planetary boundaries concept set out in the original paper. In 2015, a second paper was published in ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' to update the Planetary Boundaries concept and findings were presented at the [[World Economic Forum]] in Davos, January 2015. A 2018 study, co-authored by Rockström, calls into question the international agreement to limit warming to 2 degrees above pre-industrial temperatures set forth in the [[Paris Agreement]]. The scientists raise the possibility that even if [[greenhouse gas]] emissions are [[Climate change mitigation|substantially reduced]] to limit warming to 2 degrees, that might be the "threshold" at which self-reinforcing [[climate feedbacks]] add additional warming until the [[Climate|climate system]] stabilizes in a [[Climate state#Hothouse|hothouse climate state]]. This would make parts of the world uninhabitable, raise sea levels by up to {{convert|60|m|ft}}, and raise temperatures by {{convert|4-5|C-change}} to levels that are higher than any [[interglacial]] period in the past 1.2 million years. Rockström notes that whether this would occur "is one of the most existential questions in science." Study author Katherine Richardson stresses, "We note that the Earth has never in its history had a quasi-stable state that is around 2 °C warmer than the preindustrial and suggest that there is substantial risk that the system, itself, will ‘want’ to continue warming because of all of these other processes – even if we stop emissions. This implies not only reducing emissions but much more.”{{cite journal|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2018/07/31/1810141115|doi=10.1073/pnas.1810141115|journal=PNAS|title=Trajectories of the Earth System in the Anthropocene|authors=Steffen et al.|year=2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/aug/06/domino-effect-of-climate-events-could-push-earth-into-a-hothouse-state|work=The Guardian|title=Domino-effect of climate events could push Earth into a ‘hothouse’ state|last=Watts|first=Jonathan|date=2018-08-07|accessdate=2018-08-08}} ==Background== [[File:Terra.png|thumb|The planet [[Earth]] is a finite system, which means it has limits.]] ===The idea=== The idea that our planet has limits, including the burden placed upon it by human activities, has been around for some time. In 1972, ''[[The Limits to Growth]]'' was published. It presented a model in which five variables: [[world population]], industrialization, pollution, food production, and [[resources depletion]], are examined, and considered to grow [[exponential growth|exponentially]], whereas the ability of technology to increase resources availability is only [[linear function|linear]].{{Harvnb|Meadows|others|1972}}. Subsequently, the report was widely dismissed, particularly by economists and businessmen,{{Harvnb|Meyer|Nørgård|2010}}. and it has often been claimed that history has proved the projections to be incorrect.{{Harvnb|van Vuuren|Faber|2009}}, p. 23. In 2008, Graham Turner from the [[Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation]] (CSIRO) published "A comparison of ''The Limits to Growth'' with thirty years of reality".{{Harvnb|Turner|2008}}, p. 37. Turner found that the observed historical data from 1970 to 2000 closely matches the simulated results of the "standard run" limits of growth model for almost all the outputs reported. "The comparison is well within uncertainty bounds of nearly all the data in terms of both magnitude and the trends over time." Turner also examined a number of reports, particularly by economists, which over the years have purported to discredit the limits-to-growth model. Turner says these reports are flawed, and reflect misunderstandings about the model. In 2010, Nørgård, Peet and Ragnarsdóttir called the book a "pioneering report", and said that it "has withstood the test of time and, indeed, has only become more relevant."{{Harvnb|Nørgård|Peet|Ragnarsdóttir|2010}}. {{quote box | quote = With few exceptions, economics as a discipline has been dominated by a perception of living in an unlimited world, where resource and pollution problems in one area were solved by moving resources or people to other parts. The very hint of any global limitation as suggested in the report ''The Limits to Growth'' was met with disbelief and rejection by businesses and most economists. However, this conclusion was mostly based on false premises. |source = – {{Harvtxt|Meyer|Nørgård|2010}}. | align = right | width = 25% | bgcolor = #f8f8f8 | qalign = left | salign = right }} ''[[Our Common Future]]''Also known as the {{Harvnb|Brundtland Report|1987}}. was published in 1987 by United Nations' [[Brundtland Commission|World Commission on Environment and Development]]. It tried to recapture the spirit of the [[United Nations Conference on the Human Environment|Stockholm Conference]]. Its aim was to interlock the concepts of development and environment for future political discussions. It introduced the famous definition for [[sustainable development]]: {{quote|"Development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs."|''{{Harvnb|Brundtland Report|1987}}''}} Of a different kind is the approach made by [[James Lovelock]]. In the 1970s he and [[microbiologist]] [[Lynn Margulis]] presented the [[Gaia hypothesis|Gaia theory or hypothesis]], that states that all [[organisms]] and their [[inorganic]] surroundings on Earth are integrated into a single self-regulating system.{{Harvnb|Lovelock|1972}}; {{Harvnb|Lovelock|Margulis|1974}}. The system has the ability to react to perturbations or deviations, much like a living organism adjusts its regulation mechanisms to accommodate environmental changes such as temperature ([[homeostasis]]). Nevertheless, this capacity has limits. For instance, when a living organism is subjected to a temperature that is lower or higher than its living range, it can perish because its regulating mechanism cannot make the necessary adjustments. Similarly the Earth may not be able to react to large deviations in critical parameters. In his book ''[[The Revenge of Gaia]]'', he affirms that the destruction of rainforests and biodiversity, compounded with the increase of [[greenhouse gas]]es made by humans, is producing [[global warming]]. ===From Holocene to Anthropocene=== {{Main|Anthropocene}} {{quote box | quote = Our planet’s ability to provide an accommodating environment for humanity is being challenged by our own activities. The environment—our life-support system—is changing rapidly from the stable Holocene state of the last 12,000 years, during which we developed agriculture, villages, cities, and contemporary civilizations, to an unknown future state of significantly different conditions. |source = – {{Harvtxt|Steffen|Rockström|Costanza|2011}} | align = right | width = 25% | bgcolor = #f8f8f8 | qalign = left | salign = right }} The [[Holocene]] began about 10,000 years ago. It is the current [[interglacial]] period, and it has proven to be a relatively stable environment of the Earth. There have been natural environmental fluctuations during the Holocene, but the key atmospheric and biogeochemical parameters have been relatively stable.{{Harvnb|Dansgaard|others1993}}; {{Harvnb|Petit|others|1999}}; {{Harvnb|Rioual|others|2001}}. This stability and [[Resilience (ecology)|resilience]] has allowed agriculture to develop and complex societies to thrive.{{Harvnb|van der Leeuw|2008}}. According to Rockström ''et al.'', we "have now become so dependent on those investments for our way of life, and how we have organized society, technologies, and economies around them, that we must take the range within which Earth System processes varied in the Holocene as a scientific reference point for a desirable planetary state." {{external media |align=right |width=300px |image1=[http://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art32/figure1.html The last glacial cycle of δ18O] indicative of the stability of the Holocene over the last 10,000 years
– Adapted from {{Harvtxt|Young|Steffen|2009}} }} Since the [[industrial revolution]], according to [[Paul J. Crutzen|Paul Crutzen]], Will Steffen and others, the planet has entered a new epoch, the [[Anthropocene]]. In the Anthropocene, humans have become the main agents of change to the Earth system.{{Harvnb|Crutzen|2002}}; {{Harvnb|Steffen|Crutzen|McNeill|2007}}; {{Harvnb|Zalasiewicz|others|2010}}. There have been well publicized scientific warnings about risks in the areas of climate change and stratospheric ozone.{{Harvnb|IPCC AR4 WG2|2007}}{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}; {{Harvnb|WMO|2011}}. However, other [[biophysical]] processes are also important.{{Harvnb|Mace|Masundire|Baillie|2005}}; {{Harvnb|Folke|others|2004}}; {{Harvnb|Gordon|Peterson|Bennett|2008}}. For example, since the advent of the Anthropocene, the rate at which species are being extinguished has increased over 100 times,{{Harvnb|Mace|Masundire|Baillie|2005}}. and humans are now the driving force altering global river flows{{Harvnb|Shiklomanov|Rodda|2003}}. as well as water vapor flows from the land surface.{{Harvnb|Gordon|Peterson|Bennett|2008}}. Continuing pressure on the Earth's biophysical systems from human activities raises concerns that further pressure could be destabilizing, and precipitate sudden or irreversible changes to the environment. According to Rockström et al., "Up to 30% of all mammal, bird, and amphibian species will be threatened with extinction this century."{{Cite journal|last=Rockström|first=John|date=2009|title=Planetary Boundaries: Exploring the Safe Operating Space for Humanity|url=|journal=Ecology and society : a journal of integrative science for resilience and sustainability|volume=14 |issue=2|pages=473|via=}} It is difficult to address the issue, because the predominant paradigms of social and economic development are largely indifferent to the looming possibilities of large scale environmental disasters triggered by humans.{{Harvnb|Stern|2007}}{{Harvnb|Rockström|Steffen|26 others|2009}} Legal boundaries can help keep human activities in check, but are only as effective as the political will to make and enforce them.{{Cite journal |last=Chapron|first=Guillaume |last2=Epstein|first2=Yaffa |last3=Trouwborst|first3=Arie |last4=López-Bao|first4=José Vicente |date=February 2017 |title=Bolster legal boundaries to stay within planetary boundaries |url=http://www.nature.com/articles/s41559-017-0086 |journal=Nature Ecology & Evolution |volume=1 |pages=1–5|doi=10.1038/s41559-017-0086}} {{clear}} ==Nine boundaries== '''Thresholds and boundaries''' The ''threshold'', or climatological [[Tipping point (climatology)|tipping point]], is the value at which a very small increment for the control variable (like CO2) produces a large, possibly catastrophic, change in the response variable (global warming). The threshold points are difficult to locate, because the Earth System is very complex. Instead of defining the threshold value, the study establishes a range, and the threshold is supposed to lie inside it. The lower end of that range is defined as the ''boundary''. Therefore, it defines a safe space, in the sense that as long as we are below the boundary, we are below the threshold value. If the boundary is crossed, we enter into a danger zone. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="7" |Planetary Boundaries{{Harvnb|Steffen|Rockström|Costanza|2011}}. |- ! width="140px" | Earth-system process !!
