{{short description|Mostly submerged mass of continental crust containing New Zealand and New Caledonia}} {{Other uses|Zealandia (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{coord|40|S|170|E|scale:20000000|display=title}} [[File:Zealandia topography.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35|Topography of Zealandia. The linear [[ridge]]s running north-northeast ([[Colville Ridge|Colville]] to the west and [[Tonga-Kermadec Ridge|Kermadec]] to the east, separated by the [[Havre Trough]] and [[Lau Basin]]) and southwest (the [[Resolution Ridge System]]) away from New Zealand are not considered part of the [[continental fragment]], nor are [[Australia]] (upper left), [[Fiji]] or [[Vanuatu]] (top centre).<ref name="map">{{cite web|url=http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/ser/ser1997/html/figures/figure8.1.html|title=Figure 8.1: New Zealand in relation to the Indo-Australian and Pacific Plates|work=The State of New Zealand’s Environment 1997|year=1997|accessdate=20 April 2007}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=KAP03 |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>]]
'''Zealandia''' ({{IPAc-en|pron|z|iː|ˈ|l|æ|n|d|i|ə}}), also known as the '''New Zealand continent''' or '''Tasmantis'''<ref>{{cite book |last=Danver |first= Steven L. |date= 22 December 2010 |title=Popular Controversies in World History: Investigating History's Intriguing Questions |url= https://books.google.com.tw/books?id=slVobUjdzGMC&pg=PA187&lpg=PA187&dq=%22Zealandia%22+%22Tasmantis%22&source=bl&ots=FHEvzkPyk9&sig=QdDerZW6Atj9I3Z7GZq0vSrwTGc&hl=zh-TW&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwif1qGc5szNAhWCKZQKHQCADa8Q6AEIVjAI#v=onepage&q=%22Zealandia%22%20%22Tasmantis%22&f=false |publisher=ABC-CLIO |page=187 |isbn=978-1-59884-078-0 |quote= Zealandia or Tasmantis, with its 3.5 million square km territory being larger than Greenland, ... |deadurl=no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160805230513/https://books.google.com.tw/books?id=slVobUjdzGMC&pg=PA187&lpg=PA187&dq=%22Zealandia%22+%22Tasmantis%22&source=bl&ots=FHEvzkPyk9&sig=QdDerZW6Atj9I3Z7GZq0vSrwTGc&hl=zh-TW&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwif1qGc5szNAhWCKZQKHQCADa8Q6AEIVjAI#v=onepage&q=%22Zealandia%22%20%22Tasmantis%22&f=false |archivedate=5 August 2016 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> is an almost entirely submerged mass of [[continental crust]] that sank after breaking away from [[Australia (continent)|Australia]] 60–85 million years ago, having separated from [[Antarctica]] between 85 and 130 million years ago.<ref name="Te Ara">{{cite web|author1=Keith Lewis |author2=Scott D. Nodder |author3=Lionel Carter |url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/EarthSeaAndSky/OceanStudyAndConservation/SeaFloorGeology/1/en |title=Zealandia: the New Zealand continent |work=[[Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand]] |date=11 January 2007 |accessdate=22 February 2007|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Hf1Kw3GQ?url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/sea-floor-geology/page-1 |archivedate=26 June 2013 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>{{cn|reason=The current cited source says Zealandia (or, to be precise, the continental rocks that make up its two main ridges) separated from Gondwanaland (not Australia) 60 to 85 million years ago, and seemingly does not mention separation from Antarctica. Possibly also relevant is that our Gondwana article currently says Australia separated from Antarctica 40 to 30 million years ago (though this is either unsourced or not clearly sourced, and it is unclear whether Zealandia was still attached to Australia at the time)|date=September 2018}} It has variously been described as a [[continental fragment]], a [[continental fragment|microcontinent]], a [[submerged continent]], and a [[continent]].<ref name=mortimer /> The name and concept for Zealandia was proposed by [[Bruce P. Luyendyk|Bruce Luyendyk]] in 1995.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Luyendyk |first=Bruce P. |author-link=Bruce P. Luyendyk |date=April 1995 |title=Hypothesis for Cretaceous rifting of east Gondwana caused by subducted slab capture |journal=Geology |volume=23 |issue=4 |pages=373–376 |doi=10.1130/0091-7613(1995)023<0373:HFCROE>2.3.CO;2}}</ref> Zealandia's status as a continent is not universally accepted, but New Zealand geologist Nick Mortimer has commented that "if it wasn't for the ocean" it would have been recognized as such long ago.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencenewsforstudents.org/article/zealandia-continent |title=Zealandia continent}}</ref>
The land mass may have been completely submerged about 23 million years ago,<ref>{{cite news|title=Searching for the lost continent of Zealandia|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/4219871a11.html?source=RSSnationalnews_20070929|work=The [[The Dominion Post (Wellington)|Dominion Post]] |date=29 September 2007 |accessdate=9 October 2007 |quote=We cannot categorically say that there has always been land here. The geological evidence at present is too weak, so we are logically forced to consider the possibility that the whole of Zealandia may have sunk.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=In Search of Ancient New Zealand |last=Campbell |first=Hamish |author2=Gerard Hutching |year=2007 |publisher=[[Penguin Books]] |location=North Shore, New Zealand |isbn=978-0-14-302088-2 |pages=166–167}}</ref> and most of it (93%) remains submerged beneath the [[Pacific Ocean]].<ref name="UNCLOS">{{cite book |last1=Wood |first1=Ray |first2=Vaughan |last2=Stagpoole |first3=Ian |last3=Wright |first4=Bryan |last4=Davy |first5=Phil |last5=Barnes |title=New Zealand's Continental Shelf and UNCLOS Article 76 |url=http://www.gns.cri.nz/research/marine/images/unclosbook_print.pdf |format=PDF |access-date=22 February 2007 |series=Institute of Geological and Nuclear Sciences series 56 |id=NIWA technical report 123 |year=2003 |department=Institute of Geological and Nuclear Sciences Limited |publisher=National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research |location=Wellington, New Zealand |page=16 |quote=The continuous rifted basement structure, thickness of the crust, and lack of seafloor spreading anomalies are evidence of prolongation of the New Zealand land mass to Gilbert Seamount. |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070221051420/http://www.gns.cri.nz/research/marine/images/unclosbook_print.pdf |archivedate=21 February 2007 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> With a total area of approximately {{convert|4920000|km2|mi2|abbr=on}}, it is the world's largest current [[continental fragment|microcontinent]], more than twice the size of the next-largest microcontinent and more than half the size of the [[Australia (continent)|Australian continent]]. As such, and due to other geological considerations, such as crustal thickness and density, it is arguably a [[continent]] in its own right.<ref name=MortimerCampbell2014>{{cite book |last1=Mortimer |first1=Nick |first2=Hamish |last2=Campbell |date=2014 |title=Zealandia: Our continent revealed |location=North Shore, New Zealand |publisher=Penguin Books |pages=72 ff |ISBN=978-0-14-357156-8}}</ref> This was the argument which made news in 2017,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-39000936 |title=Zealandia: Is there an eighth continent under New Zealand? |date=2017-02-17 |publisher=BBC News |access-date=2017-03-26 |language=en-GB |deadurl=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170328203049/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-39000936 |archive-date=28 March 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> when geologists from [[New Zealand]], [[New Caledonia]], and Australia concluded that Zealandia fulfills all the requirements to be considered a continent, rather than a microcontinent or continental fragment.<ref name=mortimer />
Zealandia supports substantial [[Fishing industry in New Zealand|inshore fisheries]] and contains gas fields, of which the largest known is New Zealand's [[Maui gas field]], near [[Taranaki]]. Permits for oil exploration in the [[Great South Basin]] were issued in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crownminerals.govt.nz/cms/about/media-centre/great-south-basin-media-pack-1/great-south-basin-questions-and-answers|title=Great South Basin – Questions and Answers |date=11 July 2007 |access-date=18 April 2008 |deadurl=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014080132/http://www.crownminerals.govt.nz/cms/about/media-centre/great-south-basin-media-pack-1/great-south-basin-questions-and-answers |archive-date=14 October 2008 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Offshore mineral resources include [[iron sands]], [[Volcanogenic massive sulfide ore deposit|volcanic massive sulfides]] and [[ferromanganese nodule]] deposits.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crownminerals.govt.nz/cms/news/2006/new-survey-published-on-nz-mineral-deposits |title=New survey published on NZ mineral deposits |date=30 May 2007 |accessdate=18 April 2008 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016202631/http://www.crownminerals.govt.nz/cms/news/2006/new-survey-published-on-nz-mineral-deposits |archive-date=16 October 2008 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Geology == [[File:Zealandia, topographic map.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35|Topographic map of Zealandia]] [[File:Ball's Pyramid2.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.78|Most of Zealandia is underwater. [[Ball's Pyramid]], near [[Lord Howe Island]], is one place where it rises above sea level]]
Zealandia is largely made up of two nearly parallel ridges, separated by a [[Aulacogen|failed]] [[rift]], where the rift breakup of the continent stops and becomes a filled [[graben]]. The ridges rise above the [[seabed|sea floor]] to heights of {{convert|1000|-|1500|m|ft|abbr=on}}, with few rocky [[island]]s rising above [[sea level]]. The ridges are continental rock, but are lower in elevation than normal continents because their crust is thinner than usual, approximately {{convert|20|km|mi|abbr=on}} thick, and consequently they do not float as high above the Earth's [[mantle (geology)|mantle]].
About 25 million years ago, the southern part of Zealandia (on the [[Pacific Plate]]) began to shift relative to the northern part (on the [[Indo-Australian Plate]]). The resulting displacement by approximately {{convert|500|km|mi|abbr=on}} along the [[Alpine Fault]] is evident in geological maps.<ref name="UNCLOS map">{{cite web |url=http://www.unclosnz.org.nz/acretion_map.html |title=Figure 4. Basement rocks of New Zealand |work=UNCLOS Article 76: The Land mass, continental shelf, and deep ocean floor: Accretion and suturing |accessdate=21 April 2007 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927142136/http://www.unclosnz.org.nz/acretion_map.html |archive-date=27 September 2007 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Movement along this plate boundary has also offset the New Caledonia Basin from its previous continuation through the [[Bounty Trough]].
Compression across the boundary has uplifted the [[Southern Alps (New Zealand)|Southern Alps]], although due to rapid erosion their height reflects only a small fraction of the uplift. Farther north, subduction of the Pacific Plate has led to extensive volcanism, including the [[Coromandel Peninsula|Coromandel]] and [[Taupo Volcanic Zone]]s. Associated rifting and subsidence has produced the Hauraki Graben and more recently the Whakatane Graben and Wanganui Basin.
Volcanism on Zealandia has also taken place repeatedly in various parts of the continental fragment before, during and after it [[rift]]ed away from the [[supercontinent]] [[Gondwana]]. Although Zealandia has shifted approximately {{convert|6000|km|mi|abbr=on}} to the northwest with respect to the underlying [[mantle (geology)|mantle]] from the time when it rifted from Antarctica, recurring intracontinental volcanism exhibits magma composition similar to that of volcanoes in previously adjacent parts of Antarctica and Australia.
This volcanism is widespread across Zealandia but generally of low volume apart from the huge mid to late [[Miocene]] [[shield volcano]]es that developed the [[Banks Peninsula|Banks]] and [[Otago Peninsula]]s. In addition, it took place continually in numerous limited regions all through the [[Late Cretaceous]] and the [[Cenozoic]]. However, its causes are still in dispute. During the [[Miocene]], the northern section of Zealandia ([[Lord Howe Rise]]) might have slid over a stationary [[hotspot (geology)|hotspot]], forming the [[Lord Howe Seamount Chain]].
Zealandia is occasionally divided by scientists into two regions, North Zealandia (or Western Province) and South Zealandia (or Eastern Province), the latter of which contains most of the Median [[Batholith]] crust. These two features are separated by the [[Alpine Fault]] and [[Kermadec Trench]] and by the wedge-shaped [[Hikurangi Plateau]], and are moving separately to each other.<ref name=MortimerCampbell2014 />
=== Classification as a continent === The case for Zealandia being a continent in its own right was argued by Nick Mortimer and Hamish Campbell in their book ''Zealandia: Our continent revealed'' in 2014,<ref name=MortimerCampbell2014 /> citing geological and ecological evidence to support the proposal.<ref>{{cite magazine |author=Yarwood, V. |url=https://www.nzgeo.com/stories/zealandia-our-continent-revealed/ |series=Book Review |title=Zealandia: Our continent revealed |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729235207/https://www.nzgeo.com/stories/zealandia-our-continent-revealed/ |archive-date=29 July 2017 |magazine=New Zealand Geographic |date=November–December 2014 |access-date=30 July 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, a team of eleven geologists from New Zealand, New Caledonia, and Australia concluded that Zealandia fulfills all the requirements to be considered a drowned continent, rather than a microcontinent or continental fragment.<ref name=mortimer>{{cite journal |last1=Mortimer |first1=Nick |last2=Campbell |first2=Hamish J. |title=Zealandia: Earth’s Hidden Continent |journal=GSA Today |volume=27 |year=2017 |url=https://www.geosociety.org/gsatoday/archive/27/3/article/GSATG321A.1.htm |doi=10.1130/GSATG321A.1 |dead-url=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217064642/https://www.geosociety.org/gsatoday/archive/27/3/article/GSATG321A.1.htm |archive-date=17 February 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> This was widely covered by news media.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Potter |first1=Randall |title=Meet Zealandia: Earth's latest continent |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/16/travel/zealandia-new-continent-discovered/ |agency=CNN |date=16 February 2017 |deadurl=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217050332/http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/16/travel/zealandia-new-continent-discovered/ |archivedate=17 February 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Hunt |first1=Elle |title=Zealandia – pieces finally falling together for continent we didn't know we had |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/feb/17/zealandia-pieces-finally-falling-together-for-long-overlooked-continent |agency=The Guardian |date=16 February 2017 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170226124213/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/feb/17/zealandia-pieces-finally-falling-together-for-long-overlooked-continent |archive-date=26 February 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=East |first1=Michael |title=Scientists discover 'Zealandia' – a hidden continent off the coast of Australia |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/16/scientists-discover-eighth-continent-zealandia/ |publisher=The Telegraph |date=16 February 2017 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170218202907/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/16/scientists-discover-eighth-continent-zealandia/ |archive-date=18 February 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Biogeography == New Caledonia lies at the northern end of the ancient continent, while New Zealand rises at the plate boundary that bisects it. These land masses are two outposts of the [[Antarctic Flora]], including [[Araucaria]]s and [[Podocarp]]s. At [[Curio Bay]], logs of a [[fossil]]ized [[forest]] closely related to modern [[Kauri]] and [[Norfolk Pine]] can be seen that grew on Zealandia about 180 million years ago during the [[Jurassic]] period, before it split from Gondwana.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/templates/page.aspx?id=35598 |title=Fossil forest: Features of Curio Bay/Porpoise Bay |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081017015051/http://www.doc.govt.nz/templates/page.aspx?id=35598 |archive-date=17 October 2008 |access-date=6 November 2007}}</ref> These were buried by volcanic mud flows and gradually replaced by [[silica]] to produce the fossils now exposed by the sea.
During glacial periods, more of Zealandia becomes a [[Terrestrial ecoregion|terrestrial]] rather than a marine environment. Zealandia was originally thought to have no native land [[mammal]] fauna, but [[Saint Bathans mammal|the discovery in 2006 of a fossil mammal jaw]] from the [[Miocene]] in the [[Otago]] region shows otherwise.<ref>{{cite book |title=In Search of Ancient New Zealand |last1=Campbell |first1=Hamish |author2=Gerard Hutching |year=2007 |publisher=Penguin Books |location=North Shore, New Zealand |isbn=978-0-14-302088-2 |pages=183–184}}</ref>
== Political divisions == [[File:Zealandia EEZs.tif|thumb|right|[[Exclusive economic zone]] of New Zealand and continental shelf boundaries for much of Zealandia]]
The total land area (including [[internal waters|inland water bodies]]) of Zealandia is {{convert|286655|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}. Of this, [[New Zealand]] comprises the majority, at {{convert|267988|km2|sqmi|abbr=on|disp=x| (}}, or 93%) which includes the mainland, nearby islands, and most outlying islands including the [[Antipodes Islands]], [[Auckland Islands]], [[Bounty Islands]], [[Campbell Islands]], and [[Chatham Islands]] (but not the [[Kermadec Islands]] or [[Macquarie Island]] ([[Australia]]), which are part of the rift).
[[New Caledonia]] and the islands surrounding it comprise some {{convert|18576|km2|sqmi|abbr=on|disp=x| (}} or 7%) and the remainder is made up of various [[States and territories of Australia|territories]] of [[Australia]] including [[Lord Howe Island]] Group ([[New South Wales]]) at {{convert|56|km2|sqmi|abbr=on|disp=x| (}} or 0.02%), [[Norfolk Island]] at {{convert|35|km2|sqmi|abbr=on|disp=x| (}} or 0.01%), as well as [[Elizabeth Reef|Elizabeth]] and [[Middleton Reef]]s ([[Coral Sea Islands]] Territory) with {{convert|0.25|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}.
